metadata.title: Synergistic N-P coordination enables low-melting, high-crystallinity syndiotactic 1,2-polybutadiene via iron-based catalyst

Synergistic N-P coordination enables low-melting, high-crystallinity syndiotactic 1,2-polybutadiene via iron-based catalyst Lihua Na Investigation Data curation 1 Yunqing Fan Validation Data curation 1 Liang Fang Investigation Data curation ⁎ Xiaohua Wang Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Heng Liu Project administration Formal analysis Chunyu Zhang Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition ⁎ Xuequan Zhang Validation Project administration Qi Yang Writing – review & editing Project administration Funding acquisition Conceptualization ⁎ Key laboratory of Advanced Rubber Material, Ministry of Education, Key Lab of Rubber-Plastics, Ministry of Education/Shandong Provincial Key Lab of Rubber-Plastics, School of Polymer Science and Engineering, Qingdao University of Science & Technology, Qingdao 266042, China Key laboratory of Advanced Rubber Material, Ministry of Education, Key Lab of Rubber-Plastics, Ministry of Education/Shandong Provincial Key Lab of Rubber-Plastics, School of Polymer Science and Engineering, Qingdao University of Science & Technology Qingdao 266042 China Key laboratory of Advanced Rubber Material, Ministry of Education, Key Lab of Rubber-Plastics, Ministry of Education/Shandong Provincial Key Lab of Rubber-plastics, School of Polymer Science and Engineering, Qingdao University of Science & Technology, Qingdao, 266042, China ⁎ Corresponding authors. 1 Lihua Na and Yunqing Fan contribute equally to this work. Syndiotactic 1,2-polybutadiene (SPB) is promising crystalline material with high wear resistance, yet its practical applications remain limited due to excessively high melting temperature (Tₘ), which hinder melt processing. In this study, we report a novel iron-based catalyst system, Fe(acac)3/AIBN/PPh3/AlR3, that enables the synthesis of SPB with low melting temperature (T m) (< 120 °C) and relatively high crystallinity (up to 18 %), thereby addressing a long-standing challenge. The catalyst design features a synergistic N-P coordination strategy: AIBN serves as the primary ligand, coordinating to the Fe center via cyano groups to modulate its electronic and steric environment, effectively lowering Tₘ while promoting syndiotactic monomer insertion. Meanwhile, PPh3 functions as an auxiliary ligand, enhancing stereoselectivity by fine-tuning the coordination geometry through its strong σ-donating character. Comparative studies reveal that the presence of PPh3 significantly improves the syndiotacticity and crystallinity of the resulting polymers without compromising catalytic activity. This work not only provides a simple and scalable catalyst platform for producing processable crystalline polybutadiene, but also offers new mechanistic insights into ligand field modulation for stereocontrol in Fe-catalyzed diene polymerizations, paving the way for future advances in tunable diene synthesis. Graphical Abstract Keywords Syndiotactic-1,2-polybutadiene Iron-based catalyst N-P coordination Stereocontrol Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Depending on its regio- and/or stereo- microstructure, polybutadiene (PB) is capable of demonstrating distinctly different mechanical properties, that play a pivotal role in governing its application fields [1–5]. Cis-1,4-PB performs excellent elasticity, and serves as the primary elastomer for the current tire industry; trans-1,4-PB, known for its rigidity, is used in applications requiring high mechanical strength [6,7]; syn-/iso-1,2-PB are crystalline polymers valued for their wear-resistance, and serve the shoe sole market [8,9]. In contrast to the wide applications of cis-/trans-1,4-PB, syn-/iso-1,2-PB are comparatively underutilized. One of the possible reasons lies in that these two polymers feature high crystallinity and hence are accompanied with very high melting temperature (T m typically > 150 °C), which brings in a severe processability problem because the pendent CC double bond may undergo crosslinking upon melting. Typically, highly crystalline syndiotactic 1,2-PB exhibits Tₘ values in the range of ∼120–190 °C (sometimes up to 200 °C), far above the processing window where undesired crosslinking may occur. Based on this consideration, preparing syn-/iso-1,2-PB that maintain high crystallinity but possess a lower T m (preferably below 120 °C) could fully resolve the above processing issue and greatly expand their potential applications. Among the two stereoregular forms of 1,2-PB, iso-1,2-PB is more synthetically challenging because it requires consecutive same-side insertions in a 1,2-fashion, a pathway that is sterically demanding and thermodynamically disfavored for most coordination catalysts [8]; thus, it has so far been accessible only via a few specially designed chromium-based systems [10]. Consequently, most academic research and industrial interest have been largely concentrated on the syn form [8,10]. Over the past decades, a variety of catalytic systems-based on vanadium (V) [11], cobalt (Co) [12,13], chromium (Cr) [14,15], and iron (Fe) [16] have been developed to promote the stereospecific polymerization of 1,3-butadiene (BD) to syndiotactic 1,2-polybutadiene (SPB). Compared with representative Co- and Cr-based catalysts that usually rely on CS2 or toxic halogenated/aromatic solvents (Table S1), and are also inherently toxic to humans, Fe-based catalysts stand out due to their low toxicity, earth abundance, and environmental sustainability [17–19]. Our previous work focused on Fe catalysts bearing phosphorus ligands, such as phosphite or phosphate derivatives, which yielded SPB with high crystallinity and T m exceeding 150 °C, suitable for reinforcing rubber composites [20–23]. However, efforts to lower T m by either decreasing aluminum alkyl loading or increasing phosphorus ligand content resulted in excessively reduced crystallinity or even loss of stereoregularity, leading to atactic 1,2-PB [24]. To overcome these challenges, several Fe-based systems incorporating nitrogen ligands have been explored. For instance, Ricci et al. demonstrated that FeCl₂(bipyridine)₂/MAO and FeCl₂(phenanthroline)/MAO catalysts could produce SPB with T m below 140 °C [19,25], while FeCl₂(iminopyridine)/MAO complexes further lowered T m to the range of 68 °C to 106 °C [26,27]. Nevertheless, existing systems still face intrinsic limitations: (1) Phosphorus-based ligands, despite their strong σ-donor ability to enhance syndiotacticity (pentad rrrr: 65–95 %), overly increase the electron density of the Fe center, thereby limiting the tunability of T m; (2) Nitrogen-based ligands, while being weaker σ-donors that facilitate modulation of the metal center’s electronic environment, typically suffer from low coordination strength and thermal stability, resulting in ligand dissociation and catalyst deactivation at elevated temperature. These limitations underscore the need for alternative ligand frameworks that balance electronic modulation with robust coordination stability to achieve both stereocontrol and desirable crystallization behavior in SPB. To this end, we report a novel Fe-based catalytic system, Fe(acac)3/AIBN/PPh3/AlR3, that leverages a synergistic nitrogen-phosphorus coordination strategy to achieve stereospecific 1,2-polymerization of BD. In this design, AIBN functions as the primary ligand, coordinating to the Fe(III) center via its cyano groups. As a weak-field nitrogen donor, AIBN effectively tunes the electron density of the metal center, enabling control over the T m of the resulting polymer. Meanwhile, its steric profile favors syndiotactic monomer insertion and contributes to the stability of the active species under reaction conditions. PPh3 acts as an auxiliary ligand, providing complementary electronic effects. Although not required for catalyst activation, its strong σ-donor ability subtly modulates the coordination environment around Fe, further promoting syndiotacticity through enhanced control over monomer insertion geometry. This synergistic ligand design offers several key advances: (i) it provides a minimalistic and low-cost platform using readily available ligands (AIBN and PPh3), facilitating scalability and industrial adoption; (ii) it achieves SPB with high crystallinity (up to 18 %) and T m below 120 °C, effectively addressing the long-standing processing bottleneck; and (iii) it offers new mechanistic insights into stereocontrol via ligand field modulation in Fe-catalyzed diene polymerizations, and is readily generalizable to other metal-catalyst systems for the precision synthesis of stereoregular polymers. Scheme 1 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and methods Ferric acetylacetonate (Fe(acac)3), 2,2′-Azobis(2-methylpropionitrile) (AIBN) and triphenylphosphine (PPh3) were supplied by Macklin. BD was purchased from Qingdao Ludong Gas Co. LTD and purified by passing through two columns filled with 4 Å molecular sieve and KOH before use. Tri-isobutyl aluminium (TIBA) was a commercial product of Aldrich and used as the hexane solutions (0.02 mol L−1). Hexane was refluxed over CaH2 for one day and then distilled prior to use. All other reagents were utilized as received. 1H NMR and 13C NMR spectra were recorded on a Varian Unity spectrometer (400 MHz) at 120 °C in 1,1,2,2-tetrachloroethane-d2 with tetramethylsilane (TMS) as internal reference. The microstructures and stereoregularity of polymers were determined by 1H NMR and 13C NMR, respectively. The pentad (rrrr) denotes the syndiotacticity which can be determined by the Equation: rrrr (%) = rrrr/(mrrm + mrrr + rrrr + mmrm + mmrr + rmrr + rmrm). The infrared spectra were collected on a Bruker Vertex 70 spectrometer. The number-average molecular weight (M n), weight-average molecular weight (M w) and molecular weight distribution (PDI) of the resultant polymers were measured by gel permeation chromatography (GPC) on a PL-GPC 220 high-temperature chromatograph at 120 °C. 1,2,4-Trichlorobenzene was employed as eluent at a flow rate of 1.0 ml min−1 and polystyrene as calibration. Wide angle X-ray scattering experiments were carried out by using the XRD-6100 instrument equipped with curved graphite crystal-filtered CuKa1 radiation (λ = 0.15406 nm) (Shimadzu Japan). The melting-crystallization behaviors were estimated on a Q20 DSC (TA Company) under a nitrogen atmosphere with a heating and cooling rate of 10 °C min−1. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were carried out using a Thermo Fisher Scientific K-Alpha spectrometer with X-ray source (1486.8 eV). The spot size was from 50 to 400 μm, the binding energy range was −5–1350 eV, and the dwell time was set to 100 ms. 2.2 Polymerization of BD All polymerization reactions were performed in a flame-dried Schlenk-type glassware under an argon atmosphere. In a general procedure, BD in hexane (1.85 mol L−1) was firstly charged into a glassware, then a predetermined amount of Fe(acac)3, AIBN, PPh3 and TIBA were injected into the glassware in order. After the polymerization was kept at 50 °C for 2 h, the reaction was immediately terminated by adding of acidified ethanol containing 1.0 wt% 2,6-di-tert-butyl-4-methylphenol (BHT) as antioxidant reagent. This quench step also converts remaining alkylaluminum species into ethanol-soluble aluminum salts, which were removed by washing. The polymer was isolated by filtration and dried in a vacuum oven at 45 °C overnight to constant weight. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and characterization of 1,2-PB with Fe(acac)3/AIBN/TIBA system In the past decades, transition metal complexes with imine derivative ligands have represented a class of powerful catalysts to polymerize conjugated dienes. The pivotal structure of such catalysts is the coordination of an imine group(CN) as the donor to the metal cationic active species [28,29]. AIBN, a common free radical initiator that contains an azo group cleavable into two free radicals at high temperature, has two cyano groups that can also coordinate with the metal center like imine groups. To elucidate the role of AIBN in this study, a series of contrast experiments were conducted under otherwise identical polymerization conditions. First, BD polymerization with AIBN as the sole additive afforded no polymer after 2 h at 50 °C ( Table 1, Entry 1). Even when the polymerization was performed at 80 °C where AIBN readily decomposes to free radicals, no polymer formation was detected (Table S2, Entry 1), indicating that AIBN also can not initiate BD polymerization under our conditions. Second, comparative experiments (Entry 2–3) confirmed that systems containing Fe(acac)3/AIBN or Fe(acac)3/TIBA exhibited no activity, whereas the ternary Fe(acac)3/AIBN/TIBA displayed significant activity, as shown in Entry 4–7. Finally, a radical-scavenger experiment was carried out by adding BHT, a well-known radical trap, to the Fe(acac)3/AIBN/TIBA system. Polymerization still proceeded in comparable yield (Table S2, Entry 2), suggesting that free radical pathways are not dominant. These results, combined with literature precedents for Fe-nitrile coordination [30,31], support our conclusion that in this catalytic system AIBN functions as a ligand coordinating to the Fe center rather than as a radical initiator. A systematic investigation of the [AIBN]/[Fe] and [Al]/[Fe] ratios (Entry 4–12) revealed that polymer yield increased with higher [AIBN]/[Fe] and [Al]/[Fe] ratios, plateauing at [AIBN]/[Fe] = 2 and [Al]/[Fe] = 20. This behavior can be attributed to the gradual formation and subsequent saturation of the active species. Notably, the M n of the resulting PB were consistently lower than theoretical values, indicating the occurrence of chain transfer reactions during polymerization. GPC traces ( Fig. 1a) revealed unimodal and relatively narrow molecular weight distributions, confirming the single-site nature of the Fe(acac)3/AIBN/TIBA system. The microstructure of the resulting PB was analyzed by 1H and 13C NMR spectroscopy (Fig. 1b-c). Resonances in the 1H NMR spectrum at 4.7–5.0 ppm correspond to terminal protons of 1,2-units, while signals at 5.1–5.5 ppm are attributed to internal protons from both 1,2- and 1,4-units. In the 13C NMR spectrum, peaks at 116.2 and 114.3 ppm correspond to vinyl carbons of 1,2-units, and those at 129.0 and 132.0 ppm confirm the presence of cis- and trans-1,4-units [32]. Quantitative analysis indicated that all samples possessed high 1,2-vinyl content (above 72 mol%). Interestingly, the 1,2-selectivity showed limited dependence on [Al]/[Fe] or [AIBN]/[Fe] ratios, with only a slight increase from 72 % to 77 % as [Al]/[Fe] increased. This stability is distinct from Fe catalysts bearing dialkylphosphite or triphenyl phosphate ligands. Such stability ensures that variations in catalyst component ratios have minimal influence on the polymer microstructure, which is beneficial for maintaining consistent product quality in industrial-scale synthesis. DSC measurements (Table 1 and Fig. 1d-e) were employed to evaluate the crystallization behavior of the produced 1,2-PB. For samples prepared at [Al]/[Fe] ratios below 15, no discernible melting transition was observed, indicating a largely amorphous structure. At [Al]/[Fe] = 20 (Entry 6), weak crystallization and T m at 111.6 °C were observed, with ΔH c of 3.2 J g⁻¹ , corresponding to a crystallinity of 5.3 %. Further increase in [Al]/[Fe] to 25 or 30 did not significantly influence thermal properties, suggesting a plateau in crystallinity enhancement. This behavior can be ascribed to incomplete alkylation of Fe centers at low [Al]/[Fe], which favors more atactic insertion, while higher [Al]/[Fe] yields fully alkylated sites that promote syndiotactic insertion and higher crystallinity; beyond ∼20, extra Al only stabilizes the sites without further enhancing stereoregularity. These results indicate that altering polymerization parameters within this system only moderately affects crystallinity, limiting its use for fine-tuning thermal properties. 3.2 Synthesis and characterization of 1,2-PB with Fe(acac)3/AIBN /PPh3/TIBA system The steric and electronic effects of ligands are critical in dictating the insertion mode of monomers with respect to the allylic-type growing species, thus influencing the microstructure and stereoselectivity of the resulting polymers. In particular, Lewis base ligands such as phosphines or CS2 have been reported to significantly enhance the 1,2-vinyl content in PB during cobalt-mediated BD polymerization. In this study, PPh3 as employed as an ancillary ligand in the Fe(acac)3/AIBN/TIBA catalytic system for the polymerization of BD. To elucidate the role of PPh3, a control experiment was conducted using a catalytic system comprising Fe(acac)3, PPh3, and TIBA but omitting AIBN. As shown in Table 2, Entry 13, this system exhibited no activity, indicating that the Fe-PPh3 species alone does not form active sites in the absence of AIBN. In contrast, the complete system with Fe(acac)3/AIBN/PPh3/TIBA demonstrated high catalytic activity. Under hexane at 50 °C for 2 h (Table 2), our catalyst remains stable and active, demonstrating markedly improved thermal robustness compared to previously reported FeCl2(bipy)/MAO systems, which typically require low polymerization temperature [33]. To further evaluate the influence of PPh3, a comparative study was conducted under identical conditions, except for the absence or presence of PPh3 (Table 1, Entry 10 and Table 2, Entry 14, respectively). Notably, the polymer obtained from Entry 10 displayed no discernible melting transition, while the sample from Entry 14 exhibited T m at 115.5 °C and ΔH c of 6.3 J g⁻¹ , corresponding to a calculated crystallinity (X c) of 10.5 %. These findings confirm that the presence of PPh3 significantly enhances the crystallization behavior of 1,2-PB. In addition to T m, glass transition temperature (T g) for the samples in Table 2 were observed in the range of −6.3 to −9.2 °C (Fig. S1), noticeably higher than the ca. −38 °C commonly observed for random 1,2-PB [34], likely reflecting restriction of chain mobility by crystalline domains. This improved crystallinity is further substantiated by wide-angle X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis ( Fig. 2a). The polymer from Entry 10 exhibited a broad amorphous halo with weak intensity, while the product from Entry 14 displayed five distinct diffraction peaks indexed to crystalline planes (010), (200)/(110), (210), (111)/(201), and (120). Our prior studies have shown that the crystallinity of SPB is closely related to the stereoregularity of the 1,2-units, particularly the syndiotactic pentad (rrrr) content. Accordingly, the comparison of 13C NMR spectra (Fig. 2b) revealed a prominent increase in the rrrr pentad signal at 116.1 ppm in the polymer from Entry 14, which rose from 17.0 % (Entry 10) to 22.7 % (Entry 14). Complementary FTIR analysis (Fig. 2c) showed that the characteristic absorption at 667 cm−1 which is attributed to the out-of-plane deformation of pendant vinyl groups in a syndiotactic arrangement was also significantly enhanced in Entry 14 [21], further supporting the conclusion that PPh3 enhances the stereoregularity and crystallinity of the polymer. To further investigate the influence of PPh3, a series of experiments varying the [P]/[Fe] ratio were conducted (Table 2, Entry 15–19). In all cases, monomer conversions exceeded 95 %, indicating that the catalytic activity remained unaffected. While the 1,2-regioselectivity (74.6–78.7 %) showed little change, the syndiotacticity index increased with higher [P]/[Fe] ratios and reached a maximum of 26.0 % at ratio of 2. This value corresponds to a crystallinity of 18.1 %, which is comparable to that of previously reported Co-based SPB, as summarized in Table S1 [35]. Further increases in PPh3 content (Entry 18–19) did not lead to additional improvements in stereoregularity or crystallinity, likely due to over-saturation of the coordination sphere caused by the steric bulk of excess PPh3. These results suggest that a [P]/[Fe] ratio of 2 provides an optimal balance between coordination and steric effects, maximizing structural control without compromising catalytic efficiency. To evaluate the scalability and robustness of the catalytic system, polymerizations were carried out at various monomer-to-catalyst ratios ([BD]/[Fe]), ranging from 5000 to 40,000 ( Fig. 3a). The results showed that increasing the [BD]/[Fe] ratio had minimal impact on monomer conversion (all >90 %), crystallinity, and 1,2-content. This suggests that the Fe(acac)3/AIBN/PPh3/TIBA system retains high catalytic efficiency and product consistency over a wide range of conditions, owing to the strong coordination of the synergistic ligands that prevent catalyst deactivation and side reactions even under diluted conditions. In addition, GPC analysis (Table S3) revealed that the M n increased with higher [BD]/[Fe] ratios, while the M w/M n showed only a slight broadening but still remained in a reasonable range of 2.24–3.12, confirming stable control over chain growth. DSC thermograms of the resultant polymers (Fig. 3b-c) confirmed consistent thermal properties across different [BD]/[Fe] ratios, with negligible shifts in crystallization or melting behavior. These findings demonstrate that the catalytic system maintains high performance even under dilute catalyst conditions, enhancing its applicability in large-scale production. Scheme 2. 3.3 Proposed mechanism Based on the polymerization results and structural analyses, a plausible polymerization mechanism is proposed (Scheme 2). Initially, BD inserts into the Fe-C bond to form an allylic propagating species, which can adopt either an anti or syn configuration. Each configuration presents two reactive sites (C1 and C3), leading to the formation of 1,4- or 1,2-units. The cis-1,4 structure typically arises from the anti-configuration, while the trans-1,4 structure originates from the syn form (Scheme 2a). The stereochemistry of the 1,2-units depends on the orientation of monomer insertion; exo-exo and exo-endo orientations result in different stereoisomers, including syndiotactic (rrrr) and isotactic diads (Scheme 2b). The coordination environment around the metal center plays a key role in determining this selectivity. In the Fe(acac)3/AIBN/TIBA system, the cyano group of AIBN acts as a weak Lewis base and stabilizes the Fe center through coordination, most plausibly in a monodentate end-on fashion as commonly observed for Fe-nitrile complexes [30,31]. However, its limited steric and electronic influence results in low stereoregularity and poor crystallinity in the produced 1,2-PB. In contrast, introducing PPh3 into the Fe(acac)3/AIBN/PPh3/TIBA system creates a stronger ligand field and greater steric hindrance. XPS analysis (Fig. S2) provided direct evidence for Fe-P coordination: the P2p peak of the Fe(acac)3/PPh3 mixture showed a binding energy shift of ca. + 2.4 eV relative to free PPh3, confirming coordination between phosphorus and Fe. Previous studies on Fe-phosphine complexes have shown that PPh3 ligation strengthens Fe-P bonds and increases electron density at the metal center, which not only stabilizes the active species but also alters the steric environment [36]. These effects favor exo-exo insertion (Scheme 2c), promoting the formation of syndiotactic 1,2-units and leading to a more ordered polymer structure. Consequently, PPh3 not only slightly improves 1,2-regioselectivity but also significantly enhances stereoregularity and crystallinity. This interpretation is supported by NMR, XRD, and DSC analyses. 4 Conclusions In summary, a series of SPB with T m in the range of 106–120 °C and tunable crystallinity were successfully synthesized using a Fe(acac)3-based catalytic system. Compared with the Fe(acac)3/AIBN/TIBA system, the introduction of PPh3 significantly enhanced the crystallinity of the resulting 1,2-PB, without compromising catalytic efficiency or 1,2-regioselectivity. Detailed structural analyses revealed that this improvement stems from an increased syndiotacticity of the polymer backbone. A plausible mechanism was proposed, wherein PPh3 modifies the coordination environment and steric profile of the Fe center, promoting exo-exo insertion and favoring syndiotactic growth. This work highlights the synergistic role of AIBN and PPh3 as co-ligands in tuning both regio- and stereoselectivity, offering a practical and efficient strategy for producing highly crystalline SPB. Moreover, achieving T m values below 120 °C, even with modest crystallinity of 5–18 %, represents a practical breakthrough, as it expands the feasible melt-processing window to ∼100–120 °C while still ensuring minimal crystalline domains for dimensional stability and initial wear resistance. The simplicity, scalability, and robustness of the catalytic system underscore its strong potential for industrial application. coredata.dc:description: Syndiotactic 1,2-polybutadiene (SPB) is promising crystalline material with high wear resistance, yet its practical applications remain limited due to excessively high melting temperature (Tₘ), which hinder melt processing. In this study, we report a novel iron-based catalyst system, Fe(acac)3/AIBN/PPh3/AlR3, that enables the synthesis of SPB with low melting temperature (T m) (< 120 °C) and relatively high crystallinity (up to 18 %), thereby addressing a long-standing challenge. The catalyst design features a synergistic N-P coordination strategy: AIBN serves as the primary ligand, coordinating to the Fe center via cyano groups to modulate its electronic and steric environment, effectively lowering Tₘ while promoting syndiotactic monomer insertion. Meanwhile, PPh3 functions as an auxiliary ligand, enhancing stereoselectivity by fine-tuning the coordination geometry through its strong σ-donating character. Comparative studies reveal that the presence of PPh3 significantly improves the syndiotacticity and crystallinity of the resulting polymers without compromising catalytic activity. This work not only provides a simple and scalable catalyst platform for producing processable crystalline polybutadiene, but also offers new mechanistic insights into ligand field modulation for stereocontrol in Fe-catalyzed diene polymerizations, paving the way for future advances in tunable diene synthesis.

coredata.dc:title: Synergistic N-P coordination enables low-melting, high-crystallinity syndiotactic 1,2-polybutadiene via iron-based catalyst
